description: Set the number of cycles taken between updating the existing plots in the user interface. The default value is 100. This controls how frequently the visual display is refreshed during cycling, affecting both visualization responsiveness and computational performance.
notes: Controls frequency of plot/visualization updates in the user interface
Lower values: more frequent updates, better visualization responsiveness, slower computation
Higher values: less frequent updates, faster computation, less responsive visualization
Setting to 0 or 1: updates every cycle (very slow for large models)
Large values (1000+): minimal visualization overhead, useful for batch runs
Does not affect calculation results - only visualization frequency
Useful for balancing visualization responsiveness vs. computational speed
For headless/batch runs, larger intervals recommended to maximize performance
For interactive visualization, smaller intervals provide smoother updates

examples.description: Set update interval to default (100 cycles)
Update plots every 10 cycles for more responsive visualization
Update every cycle (slowest, most responsive - for debugging/demonstration)
Update every 1000 cycles for faster computation with minimal visualization
Set less frequent updates for faster solve with occasional visualization
More frequent updates during long cycling for better monitoring

examples.command:
; Interactive visualization
model update-interval 20
model solve

; Batch production run
model update-interval 5000
model solve
examples.description: Different intervals for interactive vs. batch modes

python_sdk_alternative.workaround: itasca.command('model update-interval 100') - Python SDK does not provide direct update-interval control. Note: When running via Python SDK, visualization updates may behave differently
